bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 29, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses funding issues and a recent yellow fever outbreak.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 29, 1921
div1.opener:
COPY.
DIRECCCION
de la
CAMPANA SANITARIA
Contra La Fiebre Amarilla
en Los Departamentos Del Norte
Chiclayo, Peru,
April 29, 1921.
Mr. Wicliffe Rose, General Director
International Health Board,
New York, N. Y.
My dear Mr. Rose:
div1.p:
I have thought considerably about the manner in which I ought to
present an estimate of the amount of your participation in this campaign, and
I very much regret that there has been so much delay in the matter. Frankly,
I have been at a loss to know how to present this matter on account of the un-
certainty of the financial conditions of the country. As an illustration I
might tell you that although my contract with the Government calls for the pay
of my salary on the first and the fifteenth of each month, up to date I have
not been paid for either March or the first “quincena” of April. The Direccion
de Salubridad has directed the Departmental Treasurer to pay me, but the Prefecto
says that there are no funds on hand to pay with.

On April 5th I wrote you about the Lp1000.0.00 which we received from
the Government for campaign expenses; this is all we have received up to date,
and has all been used up, and we are again obliged to use of your funds for
all campaign expenses until the local Treasurer gives us more money. These
thousand pounds would have been sufficient for this month in this Department
had it not been for the purchase of the Ford, which as I told you in a previous
communication cost us Lp220.0.00. This was a necessary purchase, as we are in
constant need of this type of transportation, both for long and short trips of
inspection to places which can not be reached by railroad. This was bought with
Government funds. We are sending you a copy of the financial statement to the
Mr. Wicliffe Rose
April 29, 1921
2.
Direccion de Salubridad of the use of the funds just mentioned, together
with a statement of the use of funds from the International Health Board
for this month.

On account of the above mentioned conditions, I made the follow-
ing statement to Mr. Kirk, Comptroller of the Rockefeller Foundation:

“My principal difficulty at present is to determine the distribu-
tion of costs between the funds of the ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
and THE GOVERNMENT. If I make a fixed estimate, I may find my-
self in the position I was before, where I have plenty of your
funds, but none on hand from the Government. What action do
you authorize me to take in such a case? Now I am in this
position again.”

However with the “idea of persuading the Government to come across
with a definite amount” I am submitting the following statement of an estimate
for your approval and am sending them a copy of the same. I will include copy
of my letter to them for your information.

In this estimate I am taking most of the most important men on your
payroll, with the idea of having things so arranged that I can keep the most
important work going without any interruption. It might happen that in case
these men were working on a strictly Government payroll, and we arrived at one
of these times when there were no funds in sight that they would refuse to work
without being assured of their pay, and some of them have no means of living
without such assurance, being men away from their home circles, and I would then
be in a serious plight with a part of the work paralyzed. It is also for the
same reason that I have taken the principal employees of the Central Office on
your pay roll according to this estimate. If this does not meet with your ap-
proval kindly cable me to that effect, and I will do what I can to make other
suitable arrangements.

As you will note, in the Province of Pacasmayo, in the Department of
Libertad, I have taken all the expenses of the campaign on your account. For
Mr. Wicliffe Rose, April 29, 1921. 3.
the rest of the Department of Libertad, I have taken the most important
supervising Inspectors on your account as well as one Inspector for each of
the ports of the department. These men all consider it a compliment and a
privilege to be allowed to work on the account of the International Health
Board, which has its advantages in that I can demand more of them, and get
more prompt and willing work.

The nature of the work of the principal Inspectors on this estimate
is such that they can not very well establish fixed residence, and it seems to
be necessary that they receive traveling expenses, which I have calculated and
included. For Messrs. Secley, Richardson, Guildstrand and Dr. Mendoza I am
allowing actual expenses. For Arturo Sainz I have allowed three soles and
fifty centavos daily, for Sr. Manuel Machado who is the best of the native
Peruvian Inspectors, and who will have more traveling and supervisory functions
than any except the American Inspectors I will be obliged to allow up to five
soles daily according to the nature of his details. I am also allowing limited
expenses for Juan E. Adrienzen, Felipe Benites, Joaquin Castillo, and E. Ramirez
Aguirro.

As you will notice, I have also taken the rent for the Central Office
on the International Health Board account, to avoid being ordered out when the
rent falls due.

According to the letter from Mr. Kirk you do not plan for me to cash
your appropriation, except as we use it, which is a natural course of procedure,
On account of the unusually low exchange prevailing, I have wondered whether or
not it might not be advantageous to take advantage of this prevailing rate, if
one could know that it was not going lower. On the first five thousand we paid
$3.95 for the Peruvian pound, on the second we paid $3.62. The Bankers say they
can give no indication whether it will rise or fall. What do you advise?

Mr. Wicliffe Rose
April 29, 1921.
4.
CONDITION OF THE EPIDEMIC.

“In this Department the epidemic is under control, and the cases
are gradually declining. Our stegomya index is generally low. At the
present time the index in Chiclayo is about 2% based on the number of con-
tainers found with breeding in relation to the total number of containers
inspected. In Olmos it seems that the entire population has been immunized,
the new cases being those coming in from small villages in the interior. In
Motupe where we had probably the most severe outbreak with the greatest
number of cases in proportion to the size of the town, the number of cases
has fallen to six on hand. Unfortunately for the people, the fever has ex-
tended up the valleys into the Department of Cajamarca, but can not go very far
in that direction, and has no importance as a means of propagation to the south,
or north. I do not think the the rain is such that it will permit the reintro-
duction into Ecuador. The department of Piura is between this Department and
Ecuador, and we are continuing the prophylactic campaign in the Valley of the
Morropon, i. e., in Morropon, Chullucanas, and Tambogrande, as well as in
Catacaos, Piura, Sullana and Paita. As soon as I have inspected the work in
Libertad I intend to arrange for Dr. Quiroz to make an inspection of the work
in the Department of Piura.”

Unfortunately the land quarantine to the south has been violated, and
we have had cases in Guadelupe and San Pedro. Those in San Pedro were in
soldiers from the frontier guard. This is a condition which I had hoped would
not come to pass, but which I nevertheless feared would come, and of which I
warned the authorities of Libertad on my first visit. They have also reported
two cases from near Trujillo, but they have based their diagnosis (according
to their report) on the finding of the leptospira “Noguchi”, and I have no con-
fidence in their ability either to find or to recognize the leptospira. I
Mr. Wicliffe Rose,
April 29, 1921.
5.
cabled you about this, and will go there on the first steamer, I started
for there in my auto yesterday, but had to turn back when I reached Ucupe,
on account of water in the road.

The stegomya index in the Province of Pacasmaya is as follows
according to the last reports: Chepen 4%, Guadelupe 4.4%, Pacasmayo 12%,
Pueblo Nuevo 2.4% and San Pedro 0.6%. Soldiers fell sick after arriving in
San Pedro. The cold weather together with the arrival of Richardson, Machado,
Ramirez and Dr. Quiroz will reinforce the work in that department to the extent
that there ought not to be an extensive outbreak. Besides there has been an
antistegomya campaign in progress there ever since Dr. Carter and I were there
early in February. This naturally has not been efficient, but it has reduced
very considerably the breeding, and under the supervision of Richardson and
Machado it will soon become effective.

Up to date we have a total of known definite cases in Chiclayo of
70. How many more there have been, we can not say at present.

Referring again to the matter of the American Inspectors which we
have, I presume from what Dr. M. E. Connor told Mr. Richardson in Lima, that
we are paying more for Inspectors than you are accustomed to pay for such men.
When Dr. Carter went up we agreed that he should engaged a man in Panama whom
I would take on your account, and I suggested Lp 80.0.00, but it seems that the
agreement was made for $400.00 and traveling expenses. In the estimate I have
put both Mr. Secley and Mr. Richardson down for Lp 80.0.00 per month. Mr.
Richardson's original contract was for $400.00 per month and his traveling
expenses when away from his home station. His family lives in Miraflores, and
naturally when he is away his household expenses continue practically the same
as if he were with the family. I thought that we might take these men for the
Lp. 80.00 on your account, and the Government of Peru could pay the difference
Mr. Wicliffe Rose,
April 29, 1921.
6.
due to the low exchange.

In regard to the Libertad organization I will send you more details
either from there direct or when I return after my tour of inspection and re-
organization of the work there,. I expect to leave here on the Chilean
steamer Aysen on Sunday, May 1st, and will be there about ten days, depending
on the steamer schedules.

Our mail and steamer service here is about as bad as such service
could well be, sometimes we go more than two weeks between steamers and mail.
The mail at times (from the north) is taken to Lima, and redistributed for the
infected territory at convenience of a group of lazy and indifferent postal
employees. It would greatly help matters if you could mail me a code, best by
some Grace Line steamer sailing from New York, with Itinerary for Pimentel or
Eten. If such a boat does not happen to be convenient we will have to trust to
luck that I will get it before the campaign is finished. I have not yet lost
hope that we will dominate the whole thing before the end of the year.

We have recently been informed that W. D. Wrightson has been named
“Director de Salubridad” in place of Dr. J. Gil Cardenas.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) HENRY HANSON,
Director of Sanitary Campaign.
